0O2E254Y.title: Exploring hyperspectral bands and estimation indices for leaf nitrogen accumulation in wheat
0O2E254Y.abstract: Hyperspectral sensing can provide an effective means for fast and non-destructive estimation of leaf nitrogen (N) status in crop plants. The objectives of this study were to design a new method to extract hyperspectral spectrum information, to explore sensitive spectral bands, suitable bandwidth and best vegetation indices based on precise analysis of ground-based hyperspectral information, and to develop regression models for estimating leaf N accumulation per unit soil area (LNA, g N m −2 ) in winter wheat ( Triticum aestivum L.). Three field experiments were conducted with different N rates and cultivar types in three consecutive growing seasons, and time-course measurements were taken on canopy hyperspectral reflectance and LNA under the various treatments. Then, normalized difference spectral indices (NDSI) and ratio spectral indices (RSI) based on the original spectrum and the first derivative spectrum were constructed within the range of 350–2500 nm, and their relationships with LNA were quantified. The results showed that both LNA and canopy hyperspectral reflectance in wheat changed with varied N rates, with consistent patterns across different cultivars and seasons. The sensitive spectral bands for LNA existed mainly within visible and near infrared regions. The best spectral indices for estimating LNA in wheat were found to be NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ), and the regression models based on the above four spectral indices were formulated as Y = 26.34 x 1.887 , Y = 5.095 x − 6.040, Y = 0.609 e 3.008 x and Y = 0.388 x 1.260 , respectively, with R 2 greater than 0.81. Furthermore, expanding the bandwidth of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) from 1 nm to 100 nm at 1 nm interval produced the LNA monitoring models with similar performance within about 33 nm and 23 nm bandwidth, respectively, over which the statistical parameters of the models became less stable. From testing of the derived equations, the model for LNA estimation on NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) gave R 2 over 0.79 with more satisfactory performance than previously reported models and physical models in wheat. It can be concluded that the present hyperspectral parameters of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) can be reliably used for estimating LNA in winter wheat. Keywords Spectral analysis Sensitive hyperspectral bands Estimation indices Leaf nitrogen accumulation Wheat 1 Introduction Nitrogen (N) in cereal crops is a main element for maintaining growth status and enhancing grain yield. Leaf N accumulation (LNA), as a product of leaf N content and leaf weight, reflect not only information on leaf N status, but also vegetation coverage during crop growth. Therefore, quick, non-destructive and accurate acquisition of LNA becomes a key technique for population growth diagnosis and precision N management in modern crop production ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Song et al., 2006; Zhou et al., 2006 ), which is of significant importance for precision diagnosis, real-time fertilization and productivity prediction. Research in the past decades has shown that remote sensing technology offers the only practical alternative to the complicated, slow and expensive chemical methods for estimating foliar chemical concentrations over large geographic areas ( Curran, 1989 ). Recently, the newly emerged hyperspectral sensing information, for example, from the field-based spectral radiometers like FieldSpec Pro FR2500 (Analytical Spectral Device, ASD) or from the Airborne HYMAP data (Integrated Spectronics, http://www.intspec.com ), has the features of high resolution (<10 nm) and continuous spectrum change at each pixel which can generate more band combinations and parameter type, and thus can precisely represent information on spectral reflectance as affected by chlorophylls, N compounds, and cellular structures, providing effective means for monitoring growth status and physiological parameters in crop plants ( Yoder and Pettigrew-Crosby, 1995; Blackmer et al., 1996; Lyon et al., 1998; Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Zhang et al., 2006 ). So far, a number of spectrometric studies have been undertaken on plant N content monitoring ( Curran, 1989; Jensen and Lorenzen, 1990; Yoder and Pettigrew-Crosby, 1995; Blackmer et al., 1996; Tarpley et al., 2000; Kokaly, 2001; Huang et al., 2004; Zhu et al., 2007a, 2007b ). In contrast, less information is available on estimating plant N accumulation through remote sensing approach ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Huang et al., 2006 ), with several studies from the authors’ laboratory during the recent years ( Xue et al., 2004a, 2004b; Zhu et al., 2006; Wu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008 ). The existing reports indicated that it is feasible to estimate plant N accumulation in plant by spectroscopic means, but some of which were based on the multi-spectrum with lower accuracy ( Xue et al., 2004a, 2004b; Zhu et al., 2006 ). Though hyperspectral sensing can improve the estimation accuracy on plant N status, only the existing sensitive spectrum indices were selected in most of research ( Huang et al., 2006; Wu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008 ), which can provide not only a little complex but limited band information. Additionally, proper feature bands and spectral indices may differ with crop types and experimental conditions, and some of the spectral parameters and estimation models may not be readily applicable for practical production and instrumental manufacture ( Xue et al., 2004a, 2004b; Zhu et al., 2006; Wu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008 ). Therefore, further investigations are needed to explore consistent feature bands and construct simpler spectral parameters, and to develop more accurate monitoring models with wider applicability of crop N accumulation estimation based on hyperspectral sensing information. In analysis of plant spectral data for extracting characteristic information on target objects many methods have been adopted, including vegetation parameters, derivative algorithms, continuum-removal analysis, wavelet analysis, partial least squares regression, stepwise multiple linear regression, neural network and other derived functions, in an attempt to minimize background noise and enhance capacity of spectral information utilization and accuracy of estimating models ( Miller et al., 1990; Dawson and Curran, 1998; Kokaly and Clark, 1999; Zarco-Tejada et al., 2001; Gitelson et al., 2002; Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Huang et al., 2004 ). Among them, the vegetation parameters NDVI (normalized difference vegetation index) and RVI (ratio vegetation index) have been widely used for analyzing multi-spectral information in crop plants because they are constructed with simple form and for easy calculation, and can effectively reduce the influences of soil background and environmental noise ( Fernandez et al., 1994; Lyon et al., 1998; Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Xue et al., 2004a ). However, due to lack of effective means to analysis hyperspectral information, it is difficult to undertake a systematic quantification on all possible two bands combination of hyperspectral indices within the full range of 350–2500 nm ( Zhu et al., 2007a, 2007b; Wu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008 ), which might make precise feature bands of indicating the biochemical components in plants not fully explored and utilized. Apparently, a new comprehensive and precise hyperspectral sampling and analysis methodology is needed for exploring and identifying novel sensitive bands from the rich hyperspectral data for NDSI and RSI to establish applicable N monitoring model for modern crop production. Wheat is a main food crop in the world, and has been widely used in the previous investigations on growth monitoring with spectral reflectance ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Xue et al., 2004b; Zhu et al., 2006; Feng et al., 2008 ). Non-destructive monitoring of N nutrition indices in wheat plant would be useful for precise growth diagnosis and N saving management in agricultural production systems. Our present paper focused on the hyperspectral sensing from five different N rates and six wheat cultivars in three consecutive growing seasons would attempt to develop a new methodology for systematic exploration of novel sensitive bands and simple spectral indices to estimate LNA in wheat. Therefore, the objectives of this study addressed: (1) to construct a new method for determining the best band combinations for NDSI and RSI on the original and the first derivative spectrum in 350–2500 nm, (2) to quantify the relationships of LNA to NDSI and RSI and identify reliable regression models for estimating LNA, and (3) to evaluate the possible effect of bandwidth expansion on model performance in order to ascertain the appropriate bandwidth of sensitive wavebands for monitoring LNA. The anticipated findings, including a new approach, a series of N feature bands and several sets of monitoring models, would provide a technical basis for potential application of remote sensing technology to monitoring and diagnosis of plant N nutrition in wheat production, and be helpful for manufacturing an economic and portable nitrogen status spectrometer which is urgently needed in modern farming in China. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Design of field experiments Three field experiments were conducted at Nanjing area (118°42′E, 32°03′N) of China. The experimental factors included different N fertilization rates and cultivar types of winter wheat ( Triticum aestivum L.) during three growing seasons. Each experiment was a randomized complete block design with 3 replications. For all the treatments, sufficient Ca (H 2 PO 4 ) 2 and KCl were applied at 150 kg ha −1 prior to seeding. Unless specified, cultural management followed local standard practices in wheat production. The data from Experiments 1 and 2 were mainly used for deriving the monitoring models, from Experiment 3 were mainly used for the model testing. The following provides more details about experiment design. Experiment 1 (Exp. 1): The experiment was undertaken at the experiment station of Nanjing Agricultural Bureau for the season of 2005–2006. The gleyed paddy soil contained 14.3 g kg −1 organic matter, 1.1 g kg −1 total N, 10.4 mg kg −1 available P, and 82.5 mg kg −1 available K. Two winter wheat cultivars, Ningmai 9 (N9) and Yumai 34 (Y34), were used to represent different grain protein contents at about 10% and 15%, respectively. Four N rates were applied as urea at 0 kg N ha −1 (N0), 90 kg N ha −1 (N1), 180 kg N ha −1 (N2) and 270 kg N ha −1 (N3). The N application was proportionally distributed in two splits: 50% prior to seeding and 50% at jointing. Seeds were sown on 16 November 2005 at the density of 180 plants m −2 , with the plot size of 27.5 m 2 area. The dates for obtaining spectral data and plant samples were 30 March (jointing), 11 April (booting), 20 April (heading), 29 April (anthesis), 6 May (8 days after anthesis, 8 DAA), 19 May, 24 May, and 2 June. Experiment 2 (Exp. 2): The experiment was undertaken at the experiment station of Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences for the season of 2004–2005. The gleyed paddy soil contained 20.9 g kg −1 organic matter, 1.8 g kg −1 total N, 140.0 mg kg −1 available P, and 113.5 mg kg −1 available K. Three winter wheat cultivars, Ningmai 9, Yangmai 12 and Yumai 34, were used to represent different grain protein contents ranging from 9% to 15%. Four N rates were applied as urea at 0 kg N ha −1 (N0), 75 kg N ha −1 (N1), 150 kg N ha −1 (N2) and 225 kg N ha −1 (N3). The N application was proportionally distributed in two splits: 50% prior to seeding and 50% at jointing. Seeds were planted on 7 November 2004 at the density of 150 plants m −2 , with the plot size of 18 m 2 . The dates for obtaining spectral data and plant samples were 19 March (jointing), 13 April (booting), 26 April (anthesis), 6 May, 12 May, 20 May, 24 May, and 1 June. Experiment 3 (Exp. 3): The experiment was undertaken at the experiment station of Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences for the season of 2003–2004. The gleyed paddy soil contained 9.6 g kg −1 organic matter, 1.0 g kg −1 total N, 17.6 mg kg −1 available P, and 85.3 mg kg −1 available K. Four winter wheat cultivars, Ningmai 9, Yangmai 10, Huaimai 20 and Xuzhou 26, were used to represent different grain protein contents ranging from 9% to 14%. Five N rates were applied as urea at 0 kg N ha −1 (N0), 75 kg N ha −1 (N1), 150 kg N ha −1 (N2), 225 kg N ha −1 (N3) and 300 kg N ha −1 (N4). The N application was proportionally distributed in three splits: 60% at seeding, 20% at jointing and 20% at booting. Seeds were planted on 2 November 2003 at the density of 180 plants m −2 , with the plot size of 16 m 2 . The dates for obtaining spectral data and plant samples were 8 April (booting), 19 April (anthesis), 4 May (mid-filling). 2.2 Measurement of hyperspectral reflectance All canopy spectral measurements were taken using an ASD Field Spec Pro spectrometer (Analytical Spectral Devices, Boulder, CO, USA). This spectrometer is fitted with a 25 field of view fiber optics, operating in the 350–2500 nm spectral region with a sampling interval of 1.4 nm and spectral resolution of 3 nm between 350 nm and 1050 nm, and 2 nm and 10 nm, respectively, between 1050 nm and 2500 nm. The measurements were carried out from a height of 1.0 m above the canopy (the height of wheat was 75–90 cm at maturity) and 0.44 m view diameter under clear sky conditions between 10:00 h and 14:00 h (Beijing local time). Measurements of vegetation radiance were made at 10 sample sites in each plot, with each sample from averaging 20 scans at an optimized integration time. The saved spectrum file contained continuous spectral reflectance at 1 nm step over the band region of 350–2500 nm. A panel radiance measurement was taken before and after the vegetation measurement by two scans each time. In each experiment, data were obtained at several major growth stages, as detailed in the previous experiment description. 2.3 Determination of LNA After each measurement of canopy spectral reflectance, an area of 0.25 m 2 (2 rows and 0.5 m long) of wheat plants from each plot was collected for determination of leaf dry weight and leaf N concentration. From each sample, all green leaves were separated from the stems, and oven-dried at 70 °C to constant weight, then weighed. The dried leaf samples were ground to pass through a 1-mm screen, and then stored in plastic bags for subsequent chemical analysis. The total N concentration in leaf tissues was determined by the micro-Kjeldahl method. LNA (g N m −2 ) was calculated as the product of leaf N concentration on dry weight basis (LNC, g 100 g −1 ) and leaf dry weight per unit ground area (LDW, g DW m −2 ). 2.4 Definition of normalized difference spectral index and ratio spectral index In the present study, all possible two bands combination of hyperspectral indices (NDVI and RVI) within the full spectral range of 350–2500 nm were constructed in the form of matrix linkage. This concept and underlying content is beyond the traditional definition of normalized difference vegetation index, thus a more adaptable and descriptive spectral index was named, i.e. normalized difference spectral index (NDSI) or ratio spectral index (RSI). Table 1 describes the algorithm of the spectral indices used in this study. 2.5 Construction of reduced precise sampling method With the hyperspectral metadata in the present study, a new method of reduced precise sampling was designed by integrating the reduced sampling and precise sampling to realize fast analysis and feature extraction from the observed data sets. Firstly, the reduced sampling method was adopted to construct normalized difference spectral index (NDSI) and ratio spectral index (RSI). In this procedure, the spectral reflectance data from Experiments 1 and 2 were read at the interval of 10 nm within the range of 350–2500 nm. With the duo matrix formulation, all possible NDSI and RSI based on any two individual bands at the interval of 10 nm in 350–2500 nm were regressed against LNA, including linear, power and exponential equations. According to the changing coefficients of determination ( R 2 ), the concentration map of R 2 was plotted with the contour. From this map, the sensitive spectral range with relative greater R 2 was identified. Then, the precise sampling was carried out to read the spectral reflectance at 1 nm interval of the sensitive range identified by the above reduced sampling method, and all possible NDSI and RSI were formulated and regressed with LNA in linear, power and exponential forms by linking the duo matrix. Based on R 2 and SE (standard error), and in consideration of spectral principle, the best feature bands and corresponding vegetation indices were determined. All these procedures for statistical analysis and contour mapping of R 2 and SE values were completed with self-programmed software based on MATLAB ( The MathWorks, 2000 ). 2.6 Testing of estimation model The data in Exp. 3 were used to test the derived model equations, and the estimated results were compared with the measurements to evaluate reliability and accuracy of the equation output under independent cultural conditions. Besides R 2 , the relative root mean square error (RRMSE) and slope were used to evaluate the fitness between the predicted and observed data, along with 1:1 plotting of the two sets of values. The RRMSE is calculated with the following equation ( Zhu et al., 2006 ): RRMSE = 1 n × ∑ i = 1 n ( P i − O i ) 2 × 100 O ¯ i where P i and O i are the predicted and observed values, respectively. O ¯ i is the observed mean value, and n is the number of samples. Furthermore, the observed data from all three experiments in the present study were adopted to compare the performance of the monitoring models established in this study and proposed in the previous reports for LNA in wheat. This procedure would be helped to evaluate if the present models could be superior or similar to the previous models for monitoring LNA in wheat. 3 Results 3.1 Changes of LNA and hyperspectral reflectance 3.1.1 LNA The LNA range of the calibration dataset is from 0.09 g N m −2 to 11.60 g N m −2 , with the average of 4.31 g N m −2 and standard deviation of 3.01 g N m −2 . Similarly, the statistical parameters for validation dataset are 0.33–10.65 g N m −2 , 4.03 g N m −2 , and 2.37 g N m −2 , respectively. Taking the data from Exp. 1 as example, the results revealed that LNA over growth periods of two wheat cultivars increased with increasing N fertilization rate and the differences among the treatments varied with growth stages ( Fig. 1 ). Except for N0 treatment, the LNA first rose and then decreased over growth progress, with peak at booting or heading, consistent in two cultivars. From booting to anthesis, wheat plants grew vigorously with a high N demand, and thus LNA was significantly different among varied N rates. In addition, LNA at jointing was greater in Yumai 34 than in Ningmai 9, the opposite pattern was seen after booting. Overall, increased N rates enhanced LNA in wheat, but the increment changed with growth stages and cultivars. 3.1.2 Canopy hyperspectral reflectance With the data from Yumai 34 in Exp. 1 as example, Fig. 2 exhibits the dynamic change patterns of canopy hyperspectral reflectance with varied N rates at booting and with growth stages at N3. It can be seen that different N rates markedly influenced the characteristics of spectral reflectance of wheat canopy, with different spectral responses in the various waveband regions ( Fig. 2 A). With increasing N rates, the canopy spectral reflectance decreased in the range of visible bands, and elevated in the range of near infrared, with obvious differences among four N rates. This implied that these spectral regions are relatively sensitive to growth status of wheat under varied N levels. The similar spectral responses were observed at different growth stages, marked differences located in the visible and near infrared regions ( Fig. 2 B). This is likely because wheat canopy structure and plant biochemical components experienced sharp changes at different growth stages and under varied N rates, thus influencing the properties of spectral reflectance. As a whole, under higher N rates and more vigorous growth stages the canopy reflectance in the visible range was lower than under lower N rates and earlier growth stages, and the opposite pattern was seen in the near infrared region. 3.2 Spectral index and estimation model based on original spectrum 3.2.1 NDSI (R λ 1 , R λ 2 ) With the observed data from Exps. 1 and 2, the reduced sampling method was firstly adopted to analyze the functional relationships of LNA to NDSI at 10 nm interval from 350 nm to 2500 nm based on the original spectrum and to identify the sensitive band ranges with greater R 2 values. The regression analyses revealed that there were highly significant correlations between LNA and NDSI in two spectral ranges of visible bands and near infrared bands, whether the function was linear or power or exponential form. As seen from the contour map of R 2 with full wavelength, the R 2 values were largely greater than 0.80 with linear regression based on the NDSI of 710–730 nm and 930–1010 nm ( Fig. 3 A) , greater than 0.90 with power regression based on NDSI of 700–730 nm and 820–960 nm (figure omitted), and greater than 0.90 with exponential regression based on NDSI of 500–580 nm and 830–1010 nm (figure omitted). Then, through precise sampling on those sensitive spectral ranges, more detailed contour maps of R 2 values between LNA and NDSI at 1 nm interval were obtained in three different functional forms. According to R 2 and SE, it can be seen that among the selected NDSI groups, for linear equation the best performance was based on NDSI (R 968 , R 720 ) ( R 2 of 0.81 and SE of 1.31) ( Fig. 3 B), for power equation the best was from NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) ( R 2 of 0.90 and SE of 1.33) (figure omitted), and for exponential equation the best was from NDSI (R 940 , R 570 ) ( R 2 of 0.90 and SE of 1.20) (figure omitted). The above results indicated that the well-performed spectral indices and monitoring equations were all based on the sensitive bands from visible to near infrared ranges, whether derived from linear or non-linear equations. Among them, three NDSI models as linear, power and exponential functions exhibited exceptional predictability ( R 2 > 0.81, SE < 1.33), as seen in Fig. 4 . In particular, the power equation from NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and exponential equation from NDSI (R 940 , R 570 ) markedly enhanced the accuracy of LNA monitoring in wheat. 3.2.2 RSI (R λ 1 , R λ 2 ) Using the similar procedures, the contour maps of R 2 values for the relationships of LNA to RSI in full wavelength based on the original reflectance were firstly obtained through reduced sampling. The results showed that the greater values of R 2 were all from spectral bands located in visible and near infrared ranges, whether the regression was linear or non-linear form. The sensitive spectral ranges for linear regression were 900–1020 nm and 560–730 nm, with R 2 > 0.81 ( Fig. 5 A) ; for power function they were 700–1200 nm and 350–750 nm, with R 2 > 0.87 (figure omitted); for exponential function they were 500–750 nm and 750–1050 nm, with R 2 > 0.89 (figure omitted). Then, on the basis of these sensitive spectral ranges for each function type, the precise contour map was established according to R 2 values derived from each band. Among them, the RSI with 990 nm and 720 nm for linear equation was found to perform well for LNA prediction, with high R 2 (0.81) and low SE (1.16), as shown in Fig. 5 B. Similarly, the RSI based on 930 nm and 580 nm for power equation could effectively estimate LNA in wheat, with R 2 of 0.87 and SE of 1.26 (figure omitted), and the RSI from 710 nm and 890 nm for exponential equation gave best prediction performance, with R 2 of 0.89 and SE of 1.27 (figure omitted). These results indicated that, based on linear or non-linear equations, the identified sensitive spectral bands for RSI were almost located in the visible and near infrared ranges, similar to NDSI based on the original spectrum. Three monitoring models based on the RSI gave good prediction of LNA, with R 2 greater than 0.81 and SE lower than 1.30. Among them, the non-linear equations based on RSI (R 930 , R 580 ) and RSI (R 710 , R 890 ) had higher R 2 than linear equation based on RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), as seen in Fig. 6 . 3.3 Spectral index and estimation model based on derivative spectrum 3.3.1 NDSI (FD λ 1 , FD λ 2 ) After getting the first derivative value from the original spectral reflectance, the contour maps of R 2 values of the linear function, power function and exponential function for the relationships of LNA to NDSI (FD λ 1 , FD λ 2 ) in full wavelength at 10 nm interval were obtained through reduced sampling as described in the above procedures (figure omitted). The sensitive region combinations were found to be located in (721–756 nm and 676–711 nm), (681–696 nm and 551–601 nm) and (701–761 nm and 476–551 nm) for three function types, respectively, with R 2 > 0.77. Then, the precise contour maps were established according to R 2 values derived from all two-band combinations at 1 nm interval among the sensitive spectral ranges for three function types (figure omitted). NDSI (FD 753 , FD 691 ), NDSI (FD 691 , FD 571 ) and NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) were identified to be best spectral index for effective estimation of LNA in wheat, with R 2 of 0.80, 0.77 and 0.89, and SE of 1.38, 1.59 and 1.45, respectively ( Fig. 7 and Table 3 ). 3.3.2 RSI (FD λ 1 , FD λ 2 ) Using the similar methodology, the contour maps of R 2 values of the three kinds of functions were acquired for the relationships of LNA to RSI (FD λ 1 , FD λ 2 ) in full wavelength at 10 nm interval (figure omitted). On the basis of the R 2 values, the sensitive regions existed in 730–750 nm and 500–530 nm for the linear function with R 2 > 0.80, in 701–756 nm and 496–546 nm for power regression with R 2 > 0.85, and in 501–546 nm and 736–751 nm for exponential regression with R 2 > 0.81. Then, from the precise contour maps derived from all two-band combinations at 1 nm interval (figure omitted), it was found that RSI (FD 736 , FD 521 ), RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) and RSI (FD 532 , FD 750 ) all well estimated LNA, with R 2 > 0.81 and SE < 1.64 ( Fig. 8 and Table 3 ). 3.4 Bandwidth impact on spectral index and estimation model With the well-performed spectral indices NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), the bandwidths were expanded from 1 to 100 nm gradually at the interval of 1 nm, and then the corresponding LNA monitoring models with varied bandwidths were established based on the two spectral indices. Comparing the values of R 2 and SE of the calibration ( Fig. 9 A) , it can be seen that NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) exhibited similar change patterns. With the increased bandwidths, for NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) R 2 ascended firstly and then descended after 37 nm, although SE increased gradually; whereas for RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) R 2 and SE became less stable after 40 nm, with declining R 2 but increasing SE. Analyzing the bandwidth impaction on validation performance of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) ( Fig. 9 B), the results showed that R 2 decreased but RRMSE increased gradually for NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ). However, for RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), R 2 descended fast while RRMSE rose with inflexion at 39 nm. In addition, slope increased gradually for NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), while for RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) it decreased first and then increased quickly, with the inflexion at the bandwidth of 39 nm. The LSD test on the difference between R calibration 2 and RRMSE validation was used to assess the bandwidth effect. The result displayed that the monitoring model exhibited apparent difference after the bandwidth of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) is over 33 nm and 23 nm, respectively. 3.5 Testing of estimation models on LNA The independent dataset from Exp. 3 was used to test the six models for LNA estimation in wheat. Three statistics of R 2 , RRMSE and slope between the observed and estimated values were considered comprehensively for evaluating the performance of established models. It can be seen that the overall performance was excellent with all estimation models on LNA, although slightly weaker with the models from RSI (R 930 , R 580 ) and NDSI (FD 691 , FD 571 ). The monitoring models derived with NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) had the best performance, with R 2 of 0.83 and 0.85, RRMSE of 0.25 and 0.24, slope of 0.93 and 0.94, respectively ( Table 2 ). The models for LNA based on NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) gave good estimation accuracy, with R 2 of 0.81 and 0.79, RRMSE of 0.25 and 0.28, slope of 1.01 and 0.89, respectively ( Table 3 ). The 1:1 plotting with the observed and predicted values well exhibited the reliability and accuracy of the derived models, as shown in Figs. 10 and 11 . It should be noted that the monitoring models based on the first derivative spectrum did not improve the model performance, as compared with the models based on the original spectrum. 3.6 Performance comparison of present models with previous models In order to see if the present estimation models could be comparable to the previously reported models for LNA in wheat ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Xue et al., 2004b; Zhu et al., 2006; Li et al., 2006; Feng et al., 2008 ), the observed data from all three experiments in the present study were adopted to compare the performance of the monitoring models established in the above procedure and proposed in the previous reports. The results from both model calibration and validation revealed that based on the present study the overall performance was more stable and reliable in this paper ( Table 4 ). Especially, the models based on NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) gave enhanced accuracy and stability in estimating LNA in wheat, with a simplified and applicable formulation. 3.7 Performance comparison of present models with physical base models In order to see if the present estimation models could be better than the physical base models for LNA in wheat, we developed simple physical base models using the reflectance peaks and absorption vales following the method from Kokaly and Clark (1999) and three (red, yellow, blue) edge parameters from calibration datasets ( Table 5 ). According to our sample features and previous experience, we adopted the reflectance peaks of 560 nm, 920 nm, 1100 nm, 1280 nm, 1690 nm and 2230 nm, and the absorption vales of 670 nm, 980 nm, 1190 nm and 1450 nm for the different feature bands, respectively. Then, the models were tested with independent data from validation datasets, in comparison with the selected spectral indices ( Table 6 ). The results exhibited that the Area 670 and Derivative Red edge position had the better performance than the other parameters with R calibration 2 over 0.724, R validation 2 over 0.774, and RRMSE less than 0.299. As compared with the best vegetation index models on NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ), and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ), the physical base models did not give a better performance in estimating LNA in wheat. 4 Discussion Monitoring crop N status has been a main research field in crop remote sensing and precision management. LNA is a synthetic reflection of leaf N content and leaf weight in wheat, and thus is considered as a key indicator for plant N diagnosis and growth estimation, further for prediction of grain yield and quality index ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Zhu et al., 2006 ). In the present research, we have designed a new approach of reduced precise sampling for estimating LNA by the spectroscopy technology. By adopting the method of reduced precise sampling, a series of novel wavelengths (516 nm, 526 nm, 720 nm, 725 nm, 736 nm, 860 nm, 990 nm) were identified, and four sets of new sensitive spectral indices NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) were determined, which generated corresponding regression models ( Y = 26.34 x 1.887 , Y = 5.095 x − 6.040, Y = 0.609 e 3.008 x and Y = 0.388 x 1.260 ) for reliably estimating LNA in wheat. The present results help to lay a technical foundation for non-destructive monitoring and precision diagnosis of plant N nutrition, and provide possible core bands for manufacturing ground-based N monitoring device as well as extracting useful information from satellite and air-borne remote sensing in wheat production. Selection and exploration of new key wavebands is an important technology in the area of vegetation remote sensing and has been performed in a number of cases ( Blackburn, 1998; Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003 ). Minimizing the background impact would be helpful for extracting the in-depth band information. Several methods have been suggested to reduce background noise, including vegetation indices, derivative analysis, continuum-removal analysis and statistical method like partial and modified partial least squares (MPLS) and stepwise regression ( Blackburn, 1998; Kokaly, 2001; Huang et al., 2004; Gupta et al., 2003; Cho and Skidmore, 2006 ). Recently, some studies have extracted hyperspectral information characterized with metadata property only at some particular bands corresponding to the previously reported sensitive bands or index formulations in an attempt to establish best spectral index and monitoring model ( Wu et al., 2007; Feng et al., 2008 ). To address the metadata of hyperspectra, the present study has developed the novel method of reduced precise sampling by integrating the reduced and precise sampling, with a matrix form in self-programmed software under MATLAB 7.0. This procedure has realized effective extraction of spectral features and fast discovery of new sensitive bands from hyperspectral information in plant. This can be considered as a comprehensive and useful research means for precise data analysis and band selection on hyperspectral remote sensing for plant growth status and biochemical component. From the new designed approach, the present study found seven sensitive bands (516 nm, 526 nm, 725 nm, 720 nm, 736 nm, 860 nm, 990 nm) for indicating LNA in wheat. That is to say, the best bands for indicating the LNA lie in the regions of visible and near infrared range. The bands of 516 nm and 526 nm in the visible range are often strongly absorbed by plant chlorophyll and carotenoid for photosynthetic production, and thus can be considered as representative spectral bands of photosynthesis in green plants ( Xue et al., 2004b ). The bands of 725 nm, 720 nm and 736 nm lie in the region of red-near infrared transition, in which the red edge position (REP) shifts to longer or shorter wavelengths. This shifting has been used for estimating the changes in chlorophyll content ( Horler et al., 1983; Clevers et al., 2002 ), in relation to plant N status ( Yoder and Pettigrew-Crosby, 1995 ). The bands of 860 nm and 990 nm, located in the near infrared region, are sensitive indicators for healthy status of green leaves, and can be used for predicting the potential differences in photosynthesis and growth ( Xue et al., 2004b ). Thus, these key bands should be new additions to the reported band choices for monitoring N status in crop plants. It has been reported that the LNA in wheat is closely related to the linear combination of reflectance at 660 nm and 545 nm, independent of N fertilization treatments ( Fernandez et al., 1994 ), whereas the LNA in rice is well regressed against the linear combination of R 620 and R 760 , independent of cultivar types ( Shibayama and Akiyama, 1986 ). The multi-spectral investigations in crop plants by the authors’ laboratory indicated that the multi-spectral indices of RVI (R 810 , R 560 ) and RVI (R 1100 , R 560 ) could monitor LNA in rice ( Xue et al., 2004a; Zhou et al., 2006 ), whereas the spectral indices of NDVI (R 1220 , R 710 ) and RVI (R 1220 , R 660 ) could monitor the LNA in wheat ( Xue et al., 2004a; Zhu et al., 2006 ), applicable to different main growth stages. The recent studies with hyperspectral analysis revealed that the monitoring models derived from the hyperspectral indices SDr/SDb, FD 742 and AVHRR-GVI could give a reliable estimation of LNA in wheat under different cultural conditions ( Feng et al., 2008 ). Yet some of these spectral parameters are based on the broad wavebands with low accuracy or on hyperspectral bands with complex formulation, and thus hard to be put into practical use for development of ground-based monitoring device. In this paper, we constructed new and simple hyperspectral indices of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ), RSI (R 990 , R 720 ), NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) and RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ). The vegetation index (NDSI and RSI) composed of the visible and near infrared bands should be able to well reflect photosynthetic capacity and growth characteristics in crop plants, as well as monitor the N nutrition status in plant tissues ( Lyon et al., 1998; Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003 ). As a result, the derived models ( Y = 26.34 × NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) 1.887 , Y = 5.095 × RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) − 6.040, Y = 0.609   e 3.008 × NDSI   ( F D 736 , F D 526 ) and Y = 0.388 × RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) 1.260 ) from the visible and near infrared ranges are simple and applicable, with reasonable explanation from the principle of remote sensing. As compared with the models based on the original spectrum, the performance of the models based on the first derivative spectrum hardly improved. This indicated that the derivative spectrum cannot be expected to enhance extraction efficiency of target information under all circumstances. Identifying proper bandwidth with key spectral indices could be important for designing the ground-based growth monitoring device. In developing countries including China, reducing the cost of fertilization and manufacturing the cheap device for N estimation are of great significance for N saving management in crop production. In the present study the models based on the varied bandwidths showed that if the core bands of NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) and RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) were less than 33 nm and 23 nm bandwidth, respectively, the performance was generally good for LNA estimation in wheat. Furthermore, the statistics changed slightly for NDSI, but sharply for RSI, likely because the normalized algorithm reduces the relative difference, while ratio algorithm enlarges the relative difference. These results imply that for manufacturing the portable device for estimating LNA, we can use 720 nm and 860 nm or 990 nm wavelengths with feasible bandwidth to obtain an excellent performance in wheat. Different vegetation indices may have their specific adaptation conditions. The NDVI is a sensitive indicator of green vegetation, yet becomes less sensitive when the vegetation coverage is beyond 80% ( Cao et al., 2005; Jia and Liu, 2006 ). Thus, the spectral parameters in the form of NDVI are more proper for remote monitoring of the vegetation with relatively low coverage. In contrast, the RVI, considered as another sensitive indicator of green vegetation, is more proper for monitoring vegetation growth with relatively high coverage ( Cao et al., 2005; Jia and Liu, 2006 ). The present results have shown that the estimation range of LNA tends to be narrower for NDSI (R 860 , R 720 ) (1.22–9.50 g N m −2 ) than for RSI (R 990 , R 720 ) (0.15–9.82 g N m −2 ), and for NDSI (FD 736 , FD 526 ) (0.16–7.52 g N m −2 ) than for RSI (FD 725 , FD 516 ) (0.28–9.52 g N m −2 ), but with similar accuracy and precision. Therefore, in practical use proper N monitoring models can be flexibly selected according to the specific growth stages and vegetation coverage of field wheat so that the model types are alternative and applicable. However, these estimation models exhibited a trend of slight saturation under excess N levels, and thus have a potential to down-estimate LNA in wheat grown under high N supply. Although this excess N fertilization seldom occurs in agricultural production practice, future attention should be paid to explore additional hyperspectral indices applicable to a wider range of N levels in wheat plants. As compared to multi-spectral index, hyperspectral index can markedly enhance the estimation accuracy of several growth parameters in vegetation remote sensing ( Hansen and Schjoerring, 2003; Feng et al., 2008 ), but sometimes appear to be over-sensitive. Therefore, in quantitative analysis of hyperspectral remote sensing it is necessary to provide diverse training samples, and increase the amount, complexity and representation of samples so that the derived model can be applied under varied conditions. The field experiments in this study involved six wheat cultivars and five N fertilization rates in three consecutive growing seasons, which carries a large number of samples and rich information with good representation. As a result, the present hyperspectral indices NDSI and RSI, and their derived estimation models gave reliable performance in predicting LNA of wheat. Yet it should be noted that since this study was conducted only at one ecological area, the adaptation and reliability of the present monitoring models need to be tested under other ecological environments. This would make them more useful for non-destructive monitoring and precise diagnosis of plant N nutrition during wheat production. wP4kPfWN.title: Focal Adhesion Kinase and Fibronectin in Invasion and Metastasis of Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
wP4kPfWN.abstract: Objective:To detect the expression of focal adhesion kinase(FAK)and fibronectin(FN)in oral cancer,and their relationship to invasion and metastasis.Methods:90 paraffin blocks of oral and maxillofacial squamous cell carcinoma were retrospectively examined.Envision immuno-histochemistry with the monoclonal antibody of FAK and polyclonal antibody of FN were emplyed,and executed with semi-quantitative pathology technique.Results:Intensity and positive rate of FAK and desmohemoblast FN expression in cases with in strata profundum infiltration group were stronger than those with superficial infiltration group.In metastasis group more stronger than nonmetastasis group.But,expressions of cell FN and base membrane FN were on the contrary.The regression equation of strata profundum infiltration group was y=1.114286+0.834921x,the regression equation of metastasis group was y=-1.279621+0.638968x.Conclusion: Expression of FAK,desmohemoblast FN,cell FN,base membrane FN may possibly be a tumor pathology indicator in invasion and metastasis of oral and maxillofaeial squamous cell carcinoma.

YtP3JdGR.title: Determination of anions in acetone by ion chromatography with suppressor conductivity detection and column-switching
YtP3JdGR.abstract: An ion-chromatographic procedure is described for the determination of trace of anions in acetone solution.The application of column-switching HPLC with a flow rate of 0.25 mL/min was aimed to make low concentration acetone enrichment on guard column,in which the trace anions were separated and determined by ion choromatography with suppress conductivity.Separation was performed on Dionex ICS90 by using 9 mmol/L-Na2CO3 1.667 mol/L NaHCO3 as eluent,IonPacAG9-HC (50 mm×2 mm)as guard column,IonPac AS9-HC(250 mm×2 mm) as analytical column,and on-line injection with HPLC Pump.The recoveries were 96.21%～101.56%.Good linearity,repeatability and low detection limit were obtained.

q1TsY4S9.title: Estimating leaf carotenoid content with hyperspectral parameters in rice
q1TsY4S9.abstract: Aims Our objectives were to detect the relationship between leaf carotenoid (Car) content and spectral reflectance characteristics and to recommend useful hyperspectral wavebands and hyperspectral indices for nondestructive and quick estimation of Car content in rice (Oryza sativa).Methods Four field experiments with different nitrogen application rates and rice cultivars were conducted at different eco-sites over three years.Time-course measurements were taken on hyperspectral reflectance of 350-2 500 nm and Car content in four top leaves.We calculated the simple ratio spectral index (SR (λ1,λ2)) and normalized difference spectral index (ND (λ1,λ2)) with all combinations of two wavelengths (λ1 and λ2 nm) as well as other indices sensitive to Car,and analyzed the relationships between Car content to single wavelength reflectance and these spectral indices.Important findings Spectral reflectance varied with Car content,and the sensitive wavebands mostly occurred at green and red edge regions.The SR indices using reflectance around 723 nm combined with near infrared reflectance (NIR) or the ND indices using reflectance around 713 nm combined with NIR could be used to estimate leaf Car content in rice,among which the SR (723,770) and ND (770,713) have the best performance,with determination of coefficients (R2) of 0.897 and 0.898,respectively.Tests with an independent dataset showed that R2 values between observed and predicted Car content with SR (723,770) and ND (770,713) were 0.856 and 0.858,with root meansquare error (RMSE) as 0.072,and relative error (RE) as 11.9% and 12.0%,respectively,which indicated that Car content in top leaves of rice could be predicted effectively with these two indices.

5gIyyglW.title: Development of a growth model-based decision support system for crop management
5gIyyglW.abstract:
A growth model-based decision support system for crop management (GMDSSCM) was developed, which integrates process-based models
 of four different crops—wheat, rice, rape and cotton—and realized decision support function, thus facilitating the simulation
 and application of the crop models for different purposes. The individual models include six sub models for simulating phase
 development, organ formation, biomass production, yield and quality formation, soil-crop water relations and nutrient (N,
 P, K) balance. The implemented system can be used for evaluating individual and comprehensive management strategies based
 on the results of crop growth simulation under various environments and different genotypes. A stand-alone edition (GMDSSCMA) was established on VC++ and VB platforms by adopting the characteristics of object-oriented and component-based software
 and with the effective integration and coupling of the growth prediction and decision-making functions. A web-based system
 (GMDSSCMW) was then further developed on the.net platform using C# language. These GMDSSCM systems have realized dynamic prediction
 of crop growth and decision making on cultural management, and thus should be helpful for the construction and application
 of informational and digital farming system.

waKlI5D8.title: Effects of Nao Yikang on Enzymes of Central Cholinergic System in Rats with Alzheimer's Disease
waKlI5D8.abstract: Objective To observe the protective effects of Nao Yikang(NYK) on central cholinergic system in rats with Alzheimer's disease(AD).MethodsBilateral infusions of Ibotenic acid(IBO) into nucleus basalis of Meynert(NBM) using stereotaxic apparatus was adopted to establish the rat model of AD.NYK at different dosage has been administered to AD rats.The activities of brain acetylcholinesterase(AChE) and butyrocholinesterase(BuChE) as well as the morphology of choline acetyltransferase(ChAT)-positive cells in the basal forebrain were detected.ResultsNYK could inhibit the activities of AChE and BuChE,improve the morphology and increase the number of ChAT-positive cells as well.ConclusionNYK may be able to increase the synthesis of acetylcholine(ACh) through elevating the expression of ChAT,inhibit the degradation of ACh by inhibiting the activities of AChE and BuChE,thus elevating the level of ACh in rats' brain and improve the ability of learning and memory.

gUH29cjz.title: Determination of Micro Amounts of Iodide in Dairy by Ion Chromatography with Pulsed Amperometric Detector
gUH29cjz.abstract: A method is developed for the determination of micro amounts of iodide in dairy products by ion chromatography with pulsed amperometric detector.The dilute HNO3 solution was used as eluent and hydroxide column IonPac AS11 was selected.In the range of 0.005～0.1 mg/L,the concentration of iodide was linear with it's peak area,and the regression equation was Y=0.1112X-0.2490;r=0.9993.The RSDs of peak area and retention time were 0.971% and 0.145%The detection limit of iodide was 0.02μg/L,The pulsed amperometric detector was used in the determination of micro amounts of iodide(< 100μg/L) in dairy samples,and a recovery of 89.08 % is achieved.

ihPWAKYj.title: Copper Modified Platinum Electrode for Amperometric Detection of Spectinomycin Sulfate by Anion Exchange Chromatography
ihPWAKYj.abstract: A La3+ -Cu/Pt modified electrode was fabricated by electrodepositing process in CuSO4 solution by adding a small amount of lanthium compound,and was employed for direct current ( DC) amperometric detection of spectinomycin by anion-exchange chromatography. Experimental conditions such as detection potential, concentration of mobile phase on chromatographic resolution and detection sensitivity were evaluated. The column was CarboPac PA10,the mobile phase was 26 mmol/L NaOH solution,the flow rate of mobile phase was 0. 6 mL/min,the detection potential was 0. 68 V,the standard curve of spectinomycin was rectilinear in the range of 0. 12 12 mg/L ( r = 0. 9991) and 12 280 mg/L ( r = 0. 9995) . Without pre-and post-column derivatization,this method can be used to simultaneously determine the main component and impurities in spectinomycin pharmaceutical raw material. Ease of preparation,being applied in DC detection mode and good catalytic stability confirmed the interests of this modified electrode as amperometric sensor for the determination of spectinomycin.

cIIxNt05.title: Establishment of hypoxic myocardium model in immature rats
cIIxNt05.abstract: AIM:To establish a model of hypoxic myocardium in a convenient,easily feasible,stable,effective and duplicated manner.METHODS:The experiment was carried out in the Department of Pharmacology,China Medical University between January and March in 2000.Ten healthy male Wistar rats of postnatal 5-7 days and cleaning grade were selected and equally divided into hypoxia group and control group at random.Five rats of hypoxia group were fed for 5 hours with the mixture gas containing low concentration of oxygen(O2 of 0.07 volume fraction,CO2 of 0.05 volume fraction and N2 of 0.88 volume fraction),while no treatment was given in control group.Before and after hypoxia,the changes of respiratory frequency(RF),activity state,color of myocardium,heart rate and cardiac rhythm were observed,and blood gas,ATP enzyme in myocardial tissue as well as myocardial water content were measured respectively,additionally,the changes of myocardial ultrastructure such as mitochondria were also observed.RESULTS:All 10 rats were involved in the result analysis.①The RF was 112 beats per minutes on average before treatment.In hypoxia group,RF was obviously increased one minute later,rats presented tachypnea three minutes later,and RF was 178 beats per minute after 30 minutes of hypoxia but not obviously increased after 120 minutes of hypoxia(150-220 beats per minute);The result of thoracotomy after 5 hours of hypoxia displayed that heart rate was at a rapid level and difficult to count,myocardium showed weak contraction in the irregular rhythm,accompanying the occasional bigeminy.Both myocardium and blood colored as dark red,and blood was similar to venous blood.In control group,the sinus rhythm was 250 beats per minute after thoracotomy,and stroke was strong,blood was bright red.②Blood gas analysis and serum electrolure detection:pH,PaO2,PaCO2,SaO2 and HCO3-were lower in hypoxia group than in control group,while K+ was higher in hypoxia group than in control group(pH:7.27,7.37;PaO2:3.95,13.56 kPa;PaCO2:3.20,5.00 kPa;SaO2:65%,99%;HCO3-:19.6,21.9 mmol/L;K+:5.3,4.5 mmol/L,P < 0.05).③Activity of ATP enzyme in myocardial tissue was higher in control group than in hypoxia group(0.57,0.42 μkat/g,P < 0.05).④CK-MB content of myocardial tissue:There was no significant difference between control group and hypoxia group(P > 0.05).⑤Changes of ultrastructure:In control group,mitochondria were well-arranged and distributed unevenly and orderly,double membrane structure was clear without obvious swelling;In hypoxia group,mitochondria were swollen mildly in a lower density,nuclear membrane was clear,nucleoli were evident and chromatin clustered in surrounding.CONCLUSION:Simple hypoxia can not induce the myocardial damage,in this study,the establishment of hypoxic myocardium model only requires an easy operation,simple equipment,controlled index,and the effect is more stable,reliable and duplicated.To some content,the model can simulate the clinical status of patients with myocardial damage and provide the experimental evidences for the immature cyanotic congenital heart disease.

PWHUcji3.title: Design and Realization of a VRGIS-Based Digital Agricultural Region Management System
PWHUcji3.abstract:
In order to realize the digitalization and visualization of information management in agricultural-region, a VRGIS-based digital
 agricultural region management system (VDARMS) was developed with SuperMap 2008 as the platform of spatial information management,
 VRMap 3.0 as the driver of scene, and integrating with the existing knowledge model for crop management. This system realized
 the functions as file management, spatial handling, information query, data analysis, cultural management plan design, virtual
 simulation, and system maintenance, etc. Case studies of the system were carried out in Heheng village of Jiangyan city and
 Qinglong village of Nanjing city, Jiangsu province, China, the application results indicated that VDARMS accorded with the
 development of modern agricultural spatial information management, realized standard, digital management and visual display
 of agricultural information, and greatly promoted the development of digital agriculture technology.

i86aP7pv.title: Accelerated Solvent Extraction-Ion Chromatography with Conductivity Detection for the Extraction and Determination of Nitrate and Nitrite in Meat
i86aP7pv.abstract: An accelerated solvent extraction-ion chromatographic(ASE-IC) method was developed for the extraction and determination of NO~-_3 and NO~-_2 in meat.Compared with the ultrasonic extraction method,the ASE method has the advantages of higher extraction rate and less extraction time.The NO~-_3 and NO~-_2 were separated by gradient elution on an Ion Pac AS18 column and detected by conductivity detector.The detection limits for NO~-_3 and NO~-_2 are 2.33 μg/L and 1.62 μg/L,respectively. The correlation coefficients for NO~-_3 and NO~-_2 are over 0.99 with peak area or peak height measurements.The method is sensitive,selective and effective,and can be rapidly and easily performed.

0DE2sTE8.title: Effect of the Grain-size of SiO_2 on the PP Foaming Behavior and Mechanical Properties
0DE2sTE8.abstract: The silicon dioxide(SiO2)with different grain-sizes and different concent was modified,then was added into polypropylene(PP).The microcellular foam PP/SiO2 composites was prepared by twice-open mold.Through studying the effects of different grain-size of SiO2 particles on the foaming behavior of PP composites,this paper discussed the mechanism of the tiny SiO2 in the polymer microcellular foaming,analyzed the effecting rules of tiny SiO2 on the mechanical properties and foam structure of PP.The result showed the addition of SiO2 in different grain-sizes significantly reduced the cell diameter and increased the density of cell,and increased the impact strength of PP.The tensile strength of the foam was lower than that was not foamed.

V1RhUHsL.title: MONITORING LEAF DRY WEIGHT AND LEAF AREA INDEX IN WHEAT WITH HYPERSPECTRAL REMOTE SENSING
V1RhUHsL.abstract: Aims Biomass and leaf area index (LAI) are important parameters for indicating crop growth potential and photosynthetic productivity in wheat. Non-destructive, quick assessment of leaf dry weight and LAI is necessary for growth diagnosis and cultural regulation in wheat production. The objectives of this study were to determine the relationships of leaf dry weight and LAI to ground-based canopy hyperspectral reflectance and spectral parameters and to derive regression equations for monitoring leaf dry weight and LAI in winter wheat (Triticum aestivum) with hyperspectral remote sensing. Methods Three field experiments were conducted with different wheat varieties and nitrogen levels for three growing seasons, and time-course measurements were taken on canopy hyperspectral reflectance and leaf dry weight and LAI during the experiments. Experiment one was conducted in 2005?2006 to construct a monitoring model with four N rates of 0, 90, 180 and 270 kg·hm–2 using cultivars ‘Ningmai9’ and ‘Yumai34’ (low and high protein types, respectively). Experiment two was un-dertaken in 2004?2005 to construct a monitoring model with four N rates of 0, 75, 150 and 225 kg·hm–2 using cultivars ‘Ningmai9’, ‘Yangmai12’ and ‘Yumai34’ (low, medium, high protein types, respec-tively). Experiment three was conducted in 2003?2004 to test a monitoring model with four N rates of 0, 75, 150, 225 and 300 kg·hm–2 using cultivars ‘Ningmai9’, ‘Huaimai20’ and ‘Xuzhou26’ (low, medium, high protein types, respectively). Important findings Leaf dry weight and LAI in wheat increased with increasing nitrogen rates and with significant differences between stages of growth. The dynamics of leaf dry weight and LAI during growth exhibited single peak patterns. The sensitive spectral bands were located mostly within red light and near infrared regions, with correlation coefficients <–0.60 in 590~710 nm and >0.69 in 745~1 130 nm. The regression analyses between existing vegetation indices and leaf dry weight and LAI revealed that some key spectral parameters could accurately estimate changes in leaf dry weight and LAI across a broad range of stages of growth, nitrogen levels and growing seasons, with unified spectral parameters for each growth parameter. Among them, regression models based on RVI (810, 560), FD755, GMI, SARVI (MSS) and TC3 produced better estimation of leaf dry weight and LAI. Testing of the monitoring models with an independent dataset indicated that the spectral indices of RVI (810, 560), GMI, SARVI (MSS), PSSRb, (R750-800/R695-740)-1, VOG2 and mSR705 gave accurate growth estimation under the ex-perimental conditions. Overall, leaf dry weight and LAI in wheat could be monitored by key vegetation indices, with more reliable estimation from RVI (810, 560), GMI and SARVI (MSS).

obfEFcVK.title: Relative Research of Protein Factors CD44V6 and Salivary Gland Tumor
obfEFcVK.abstract: Objective: To probe the role of CD44V6 in the growth,infiltration and metastatic of salivary gland tumors.Methods: 107 salivary gland tumors' paraffin specimen,including 50 benign adenomas and 57 malignant tumors were underwent Envision immunity histochemistry with the monoclonal antibody CD44V6,to accomplish pathology section and execute quantitative pathology technique.Results: In benign tumors,CD44V6 only expressed on the tumor cell membrane of pleomorphic adenoma and myoepithelioma.While in malignant tumors CD44V6 expression intensity varies,but as a whole,the expression levels were higher than the benign ones.Conclusion: CD44V6 regulate the proliferation and cell attachment of both epithelial and lymphoid components in adenomas.It may be an indicators of the adenomas' malignity degree.

zhVlVwpb.title: Coupling remotely sensed information with a rice growth model by combining updating and assimilation strategies
zhVlVwpb.abstract: Coupling remote sensing (RS) with a crop growth model can improve the prediction accuracy of crop modeling at a regional scale. In this paper, a new coupling method was developed based on a combination of the updating and assimilation strategies. The optimized model was used to estimate rice grain yield at both the field and regional scales. Firstly, parameterization for regionalization of the integrated RiceGrow model was accomplished with the use of the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) optimization algorithm. Management parameters included sowing date, sowing rate and nitrogen rate. Then, analyzed values of model variables, leaf area index (LAI) and leaf nitrogen accumulation (LNA), which simultaneously served as the assimilation and updating parameters, were calculated based on the Ensemble Square Root Filter (EnSRF) and used to update the corresponding values simulated by the RiceGrow model. Finally, the growth status and final yield were simulated by the integrated model. This integrated technique was tested on independent datasets acquired from three rice field tests in different years for different rice varieties and at different treatments with regards to nitrogen rates and sowing densities. This was in addition to data obtained from study areas in Yizheng and Rugao counties in Jiangsu Province (in central eastern China), both of which are main production areas of high-quality rice in China. The test results showed that simulated values based on the integrated model were closer to the measured values than those simulated directly by the RiceGrow model, which produced RMSE values of 0. 94 for LAI, 0. 47 g/ m2 for LNA and 320. 15 kg/ hm2 for grain yield. The compared to RMSE values of 1. 25, 1. 24 g/ m2 and 516. 83 kg/ hm2 for these respective parameters based on the RiceGrow model alone, and 1. 01, 0. 59 g/ m2 and 335. 70 kg/ hm2 for the RiceGrow model based on the assimilation strategy. The newly developed integrated technique also performed well at a regional scale and the predicted results were consistent with the temporal and spatial distribution of rice growth status and grain yield, with relative error (RE) values of <20% for both growth parameters and the grain yield. This error may have been due to the limited simulation ability of the RiceGrow model, or generated during the RS information extraction and the statistical RS estimating models, all of which need improvement. These results indicated that there are certain non-determinacy factors for the RiceGrow model when used at the regional scale, such as spatial variability in the soil and management parameters. However, the integrated technique based on combining RS and the RiceGrow model could reduce this problem. Therefore, this study provides an important step towards the more routine use of combined RS and crop modeling techniques to improve our ability to estimate regional rice grain yield predictions.

QsJsuhQZ.title: Determination of organic acid and inorganic anion by suppressed electric conductance ion chromatography.
QsJsuhQZ.abstract: A new method for simultaneous determination of sixteen organic acids and inorganic anions by using eluent generator-suppressed conductivity detection ion chromatography was described.By using hydrophilic anion exchanged column and gradient eluent of KOH,good repeatability,linear relationship,and very low detect limits were obtained.Detection limits of inorganic anions and organic acids were under 0.15 mg/L.For the determination of organic acids and inorganic anions in four kinds of wine,the result was satisfactory, the rate of recovery was between 93.52% to 116.08%.

m3LouHvH.title: Monitoring leaf nitrogen in wheat using canopy reflectance spectra
m3LouHvH.abstract: Non-destructive monitoring of leaf nitrogen (N) status can assist in growth diagnosis, N management and productivity forecast in field crops. The objectives of this study were to determine the relationships of leaf nitrogen concentration on a leaf dry weight basis (LNC) and leaf nitrogen accumulation per unit soil area (LNA) to ground-based canopy reflectance spectra, and to derive regression equations for monitoring N nutrition status in wheat (Triticum aestivum L.). Four field experiments were conducted with different N application rates and wheat cultivars across four growing seasons, and time-course measurements were taken on canopy spectral reflectance, LNC and leaf dry weights under the various treatments. In these studies, LNC and LNA in wheat increased with increasing N fertilization rates. The canopy reflectance differed significantly under varied N rates, and the pattern of response was consistent across the different cultivars and years. Overall, an integrated regression equation of LNC to normalized difference index (NDI) of 1220 and 710 nm of canopy reflectance spectra described the dynamic pattern of change in LNC in wheat. The ratios of several near infrared (NTR) bands to visible light were linearly related to LNA, with the ratio index (RI) of the average reflectance over 760, 810, 870, 950 and 1100 nm to 660 nm having the best index for quantitative estimation of LNA in wheat. When independent data were fit to the derived equations, the average root mean square error (RMSE) values for the predicted LNC and LNA relative to the observed values were no more than 15.1 and 15.2%, respectively, indicating a good fit. Our relationships of leaf N status to spectral indices of canopy reflectance can be potentially used for non-destructive and real-time monitoring of leaf N status in wheat.

IP6GPJi3.title: Cardiac Function in Rats with Adjuvant Arthritis and Its Relationship with Cytokines,Regulatory T Cells and the Expression of Foxp3
IP6GPJi3.abstract: Objective:To observe paw swelling(E) and arthritis index(AI),cardiac function,cytokines,regulatory T cells(Tregs) and the expression of Foxp3 in rats with adjuvant arthritis(AA).Methods:Twenty-four Wistar male rats were randomly divided into normal control(NC) group and AA model group,12 in each group.The AA model was established by intradermal injection of Freund's complete adjuvant(FCA) in the right paw in the AA model group.One day before,and 18 and 32 days after AA establishment,body weight,E and AI were determined,and at the 48th day,cardiac function,peripheral blood interleukin-6(IL-6),IL-10,IL-17,tumor necrosis factor alpha(TNF-α),Tregs,the expression of Foxp3 in the spleen were tested.Results:(1) Compared with NC group,HR,cardiac mass index(HI),left ventricular end systolic pressure(LVSP) were significantly increased,left ventricular pressure ±dp/dtmax was significantly decreased,body weight was significantly decreased,E and AI were significantly increased,serum TNF-α,IL-17 and IL-6 levels were significantly increased,and the IL-10 level was significantly decreased,the expression of CD4 +Tregs,CD25 +Tregs,CD4+CD25 +Tregs,and that of Foxp3 in the spleen were significantly down-regulated in AA model group;(2) Spearman correlation analysis showed that,cardiac hemodynamic function parameters were significantly correlated with AI,cytokines,Tregs and Foxp3(P<0.05 or P<0.01).Conclusion:The cardiac function,and the expression of Foxp3,CD4+CD25+ Tregs were reduced spontaneously in the AA rats with increased E and AI,suggesting inflammation,and the imbalance between Foxp3 and CD4+CD25+ Tregs may be the major factors for cardiac function changes in AA rats.

sk26Spdk.title: Determination of Trace Anions in High-purity Hydrofluoric Acid by Capillary Ion Chromatography with Column-switching Technique
sk26Spdk.abstract: In this paper, a capillary ion chromatography-column switching method was established to determine trace anions in high-purity hydrofluoric acid solutions.All of the sample pretreatment and separation were performed on the newest ICS-5000 (Thermo Fisher) instrument.The RSDs of retention time and peak area were 0.02%~0.12% and 0.63%~1.89%, respectively.And the linear ranges of anions were 1~100 μg/L with correlation coefficients larger than 0.9998.The limits of detection for Cl-,Br-,NO3-,and PO43- were 2.13 ~32.61 ng/L, and the recoveries for Cl-,Br-,NO3-,and PO43- were 85.3%~103.9%.The method has been applied to analyze trace anions in true sample with satisfactory results.

m8Lo0HHK.title: Estimation of optimum normalized difference spectral index for nitrogen accumulation in wheat leaf based on reduced precise sampling method]
m8Lo0HHK.abstract: Four independent field experiments with 6 wheat varieties and 5 nitrogen application levels were conducted, and time-course measurements were taken on the canopy hyperspectral reflectance and leaf N accumulation per unit soil area (LNA, g N x m(-2)). By adopting reduced precise sampling method, all possible normalized difference spectral indices [NDSI(i,j)] within the spectral range of 350-2500 nm were constructed, and the relationships of LNA to the NDSI(i,j) were quantified, aimed to explore the new sensitive spectral bands and key index from precise analysis of ground-based hyperspectral information, and to develop prediction models for wheat LNA. The results showed that the sensitive spectral bands for LNA were located in visible light and near infrared regions, especially at 860 nm and 720 nm for wheat LNA. The monitoring model based on the NDSI(860,720) was formulated as LNA = 26.34 x [NDSI(860,720)](1.887), with R2 = 0.900 and SE = 1.327. The fitness test of the derived equations with independent datasets showed that for wheat LNA, the model gave the estimation accuracy of 0.823 and the RMSE of 0.991 g N x m(-2), indicating a good fitness between the measured and estimated LNA. The present normalized hyperspectral parameter of NDSI(860,720) and its derived regression model could be reliably used for the estimation of winter wheat LNA.

lznRkBtP.title: The effect of meloxicam on the inflammatory reaction induced by beta amyloid protein in Alzheimer's disease rats]
lznRkBtP.abstract: To investigate the effect and mechanism of meloxicam on the inflammatory reaction induced by beta amyloid protein (AB) in Alzheimer's disease (AD) rats.The rat model was established by microinjection of Abeta(1-40) into hippocampus. The expression of NF-kappaB p65 and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) in hippocampus were detected by immunohistochemistry. The content of GFAP in cortex was tested by Western-blot. The content of TNF-alpha in cortex was tested by ELISA. The expression of IL-1beta mRNA was tested by RT-PCR.The expression of NF-kappaB p65, GFAP and TNF-alpha as well as IL-1beta mRNA were decreased by meloxicam.Meloxicam can reduce the proliferation of astrocyte by decreasing the expression of GFAP in AD model rat's hippocampus and cortex. And the depression of NF-kappaB p65 may significantly decrease the expression of TNF-alpha1 and IL-1beta to lessen the inflammatory reaction in cerebral tissue.

AMyYu2OO.title: Secure Smart Contract System Built on SMPC Over Blockchain
AMyYu2OO.abstract: While smart contracts are praised widely, it should be noted that they have their disadvantages: lack of control over data protection and executive correctness or consistency. Aiming at this problem, we propose SMPC-based smart contract platform with three-layer structure: contract, computing, and group communication layer. In contract layer, we put forward SMPC-based smart contract framework, which gives the implementation process, language structure and grammar specification of smart contracts. In computing layer, fair SMPC algorithms based on general linear secret sharing scheme are designed to implement verifiable collaboration computing with input privacy and computation correctness. In group communication layer, the non-blocking broadcast is developed from non-blocking message passing interface (MPI)in order to ensure secure group communication in asynchronous networks with node and link failures. Finally, the results of simulation experiments with private currency transfers indicate that our platform is efficient and secure enough for common smart contracts.

M5B6MliZ.title: A SIMULATION MODEL FOR DYNAMIC GREEN AREA INDEX IN WINTER RAPESEED(BRASSICA NAPUS)
M5B6MliZ.abstract: Aims Accurate simulation of green area index is critical for reliable prediction of crop growth and yield using a crop growth model.Our study was undertaken to develop a process-based simulation model for predicting dynamic green area index,including leaf area index(LAI) and pod area index(PAI),in winter rapeseed(Brassica napus).Methods Leaf area expansion was simulated through the relationship between LAI and source-or sink-limited dry matter.Daily leaf expansion rate increased in an S-shaped growth curve under source limitation,as influenced by temperature,water and nitrogen levels.Under the sink limitation,leaf area expansion was quantified on the basis of specific leaf area.Pod area was calculated from specific pod area and pod dry matter.The specific leaf area and specific pod area were determined from physiological development time and genotype.We calibrated and validated the model using experimental data from different varieties,sowing dates and nitrogen fertilization rates.Important findings Root mean square error(RMSE) values of LAI were 11.15%,15.57% and 16.87% at three N levels,and the average RMSE value of PAI in two varieties was 12.92%.Plotting the 1∶1 relationship between the simulated and observed values in LAI and PAI growth dynamics indicated a good fit.Our model of green area index in winter rapeseed shows a high accuracy and applicability under different conditions.

P06mpdom.abstract: In recent years, interest has increased in using porous monolithic stationary phase media for high performance separations of inorganic and organic ions. XLw6y9b2.title: C60 reduces the flammability of polypropylene nanocomposites by in situ forming a gelled-ball network
XLw6y9b2.abstract: The thermal and flame retardancy properties of polypropylene/fullerene (PP/C60) nanocomposites were investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and cone calorimetry with the C60 loading varied from 0.5 to 2% by weight. Dispersion of C60 in the PP matrix was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and optical microscopy (OM). TGA and DSC results showed that the presence of C60 could remarkably enhance the thermal property and cone calorimeter measurements suggested that C60 could to some extent reduce the flammability of PP, with a significant reduction in peak heat release rate and a much longer time to ignition. Furthermore, the larger the loading level of C60, the better the flame retardancy property of PP/C60 nanocomposites. The flame retardation mechanism and corresponding model were proposed with the help of rheological measurements, TEM and x-ray diffraction. C60 reduced the flammability of PP by trapping free radicals in the gas phase and in situ forming a gelled-ball crosslink network to improve the flame retardancy of PP in the condensed phase. Finally, this suggested mechanism was supported by the results of advanced rheological extended systems (ARES), gel content, infrared spectrum, OM, and atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements. © IOP Publishing Ltd.

eSRXjjgF.title: Technical study on induction brazing of Al to copper
eSRXjjgF.abstract: Aimed at improving the technology of brazing,this paper presents a study of the induction brazing of Al to copper carried out by Zn-Al brazing filler metal,and the investigation into the microstructures and strength of the joints by means of SEM,XRD and shearing test.The experimental results show that the bonding of Al to copper can be performed by Zn-Al filler metal.The joint gives the interfacial microstructure of Al/Al(s,s)/ Al-Zn entectic/CuAl2 /(Cu,Zn)/Cu.The shear strength of the joint brazed at 340 A for 9 s is up to 128.5 MPa at room temperature.

e3OHza8T.title: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for patients with acute leukemia.
e3OHza8T.abstract: The purposes of this study were to assess the efficacy of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) for acute leukemia (AL) and analyze the factors affecting the prognosis of these patients.The clinical and follow-up data of 93 AL patients (median age, 30 years) undergoing allogeneic HSCT in Xiangya Hospital over the past 12 years were collected, and the potential factors affecting the efficacy and prognosis of allogeneic HSCT patients were determined.Hematopoietic reconstitution was achieved in 90 patients. At the last follow-up, the incidences of severe acute graft versus host disease (aGvHD) and extensive chronic GvHD (cGvHD) were 14.0% and 20.0%, the 3-year cumulative incidence of transplantation related mortality (TRM) and relapse rate were 16.8%±6.1% and 21.3%±6.7%, and the estimated 3-year overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS) of the patients were 64.6%±5.4% and 56.5%±5.5%, respectively. Univariate analysis indicated that age older than 40 years, HLA mismatch, and severe lung infection within the first 100 days after transplantation were risk factors for severe aGvHD, age older than 40 years, HLA mismatch, severe lung infection within the first 100 days after transplantation, and severe aGvHD were risk factors for TRM, high-risk AL and lack of cGvHD were risk factors for relapse (all P<0.05). Survival estimation showed that HLA mismatch, severe lung infection occurring within the first 100 days post-transplantation, high-risk AL severe aGvHD and lack of cGvHD were risk factors associated with poor prognosis (all P<0.05). Further multivariate analyses revealed that severe lung infection within the first 100 days post-transplantation, severe aGvHD and lack of cGvHD were independent risk factors for unfavorable outcomes (all P<0.05).Allogeneic HSCT can improve the DFS of AL patients, and severe lung infection within the first 100 days post-transplantation, severe aGvHD and lack of cGvHD are independent risk factors affecting the prognosis.

IPl5hSYc.title: Efficacy of oral fludarabine in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma
IPl5hSYc.abstract: Objective: To investigate the efficacy and safety of oral fludarabine in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Methods: The patients received oral fludarabine 40 mg/(m2.d) for 5 consecutive days, each treatment lasting 4 weeks. The efficacy was assessed with National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) criteria for response. Results: Twenty-two patients received the treatment, a median of 4 cycles per patient. The rate of complete response (CR), partial response (PR), and overall response (OR) was 40.9% (9/22), 45.5% (10/22), and 86.4% (19/22), respectively. Among the 17 previously untreated patients, 7 (41.2%) achieved CR and 8 (47.0%) achieved PR. Two of the 5 pre-treated patients achieved CR and the other 2 achieved PR. During a median observation of 24 months, the overall survival rate was 81.8%. The main adverse reactions were myelosuppression and infection. Grade 1 to 3 granulocytopenia was found in 7 (31.8%) patients, and infection in 3 (13.6%) patients. Nonhematologic toxicity was mild. All the adverse reactions were reversible. Conclusion: The oral fludarabine is effective, safe, and well-tolerated in the patients with CLL/SLL.
